#1

I’m an Alaskan girl who’s most comfortable in 55-60 degree weather, and I have been excitedly planning my Camino for October-November, thinking that I would be able to stand the temps in Spain during those months. I’m currently in Ireland enjoying those very temps and having a great time, but I leave for SJPP in less than two weeks. My weather app keeps reporting temps in the high 80s for many of the Spanish cities along the Camino, and I’m starting to fear I’ve packed all wrong for this trip. This is probably just a rhetorical question, an airing of my fears, but when will it cool down?

Dear Ruth, as usual the experience Forum Members have offered sensible (although humorous) advice.

Your Camino from St Jean to Santiago during the months you have advised will imho offer any range of weather conditions. It can snow in the mountains above St Jean at virtually any time of the year; Yes the Meseta (the high plain from Burgos to Leon) can have temperatures in the +30c (86F) degree range, but these can be overcome by starting early (say 30 mins after sunrise).

Note from Leon to O'Cebereiro you will encounter small mountains up to 1500m/4650ft so it should be more manageable.

By the time you reach O'Cebereiro you will be in Galicia the cooler weather should be with you.

As advised if necessary you can buy lighter clothing (there are 3 or 4 large cities on this Camino).

So my advise come prepared - a broad brim hat (not a baseball one), carry and drink two litres of water per day (that about 2 US quarts). Oh and just take your time, take a rest of 15-20 mins every two hours, more frequently on hotter days. So go forth and Buen Camino.

We were walking the Frances this time 5 years ago. Reading my diary it was incredibly hot every day ( high 30s) until after Sahagun on 10th October which is when we started to get chilly mornings, some rain, and cooler days.

I detest the heat and really struggled walking through those first 21 days but we would leave early before dawn to try and beat the hottest part of the day which was around 2 p.m. and I used my beloved Euroschirm hands-free umbrella as a sun shield which not only shaded me but enabled me to put away my hat and let my head cool down.

I also started to use Keens hiking sandals which were much cooler on my feet though my Merino socks gave me a nasty heat rash.

For the hot weather, I wore a singlet top with a lightweight loose-sleeved shirt for sun protection.

Impossible to know in advance, but there is a very lengthy heat wave in Europe which I think is global ,and to have been caused by a massive underwater volcanic eruption, and if so this unusually hot weather will last until about 2025, and so until the extra water vapor in the atmosphere comes down as rain.

In any case, this heat wave started in 2021, and seems to be continuing, with its own seasonality.

October-November should be OK though, they were last year.

But be prepared, bring a woollen jumper just in case, and rain kit will be a must for Galicia at the very least.
